title:
Bayesian computation with generative diffusion models by Multilevel
  Monte Carlo

sections.text:
#### Abstract

Generative diffusion models have recently emerged as a powerful strategy to perform stochastic sampling in Bayesian inverse problems, delivering remarkably accurate solutions for a wide range of challenging applications. However, diffusion models often require a large number of neural function evaluations per sample in order to deliver accurate posterior samples. As a result, using diffusion models as stochastic samplers for Monte Carlo integration in Bayesian computation can be highly computationally expensive, particularly in applications that require a substantial number of Monte Carlo samples for conducting uncertainty quantification analyses. This cost is especially high in large-scale inverse problems such as computational imaging, which rely on large neural networks that are expensive to evaluate. With quantitative imaging applications in mind, this paper presents a Multilevel Monte Carlo strategy that significantly reduces the cost of Bayesian computation with diffusion models. This is achieved by exploiting cost-accuracy trade-offs inherent to diffusion models to carefully couple models of different levels of accuracy in a manner that significantly reduces the overall cost of the calculation, without reducing the final accuracy. The proposed approach achieves a $4 \times$-to- $8 \times$ reduction in computational cost w.r.t. standard techniques across three benchmark imaging problems.


AMS codes: 65C05, 62M45, 65C20
Keywords: Score-based Generative Models, Multilevel Monte Carlo, Inverse Problems

## 1 Introduction

Many science and engineering problems require solving an inverse problem that is ill-conditioned or ill-posed [10]. Bayesian statistical provides a powerful framework to regularise these problems and deliver meaningful solutions that are well-posed [10]. Bayesian analysis is especially useful in quantitative and scientific applications that require quantifying the uncertainty in the solutions delivered, so that said solutions can be used reliably for science and decision-making [17].

Modern Bayesian inversion methods are increasingly strongly reliant on machine learning techniques in order to leverage information that is available in the form of training data [15]. Deep

generative modelling provides a highly effective approach for constructing machine-learning-based Bayesian inversion methods, both for directly modelling posterior distributions [14, 19, 18], as well as for constructing data-driven priors that can be combined with an explicit likelihood function derived from a physical forward model [15, Section 5]. In particular, diffusion models (DMs) have attracted significant attention recently because of their capacity to deliver remarkably accurate inferences. Originally proposed for tasks related to generating and editing creative content [21, 23, 9, 22], DMs are now also widely studied for Bayesian inversion, especially in the context of signal processing and computational imaging (see, e.g., $[4,11,18,14]$ ).

From a computation viewpoint, DMs are stochastic samplers that rely on neural networks to generate samples from a posterior distribution that is encoded implicitly within the DM. State-of-the-art DMs for Bayesian inversion can produce remarkably accurate samples, but they are also highly computationally costly, as producing each sample requires a large number of evaluations of a large neural network which is expensive to evaluate. Furthermore, while some generative machine learning applications require only a small number of posterior samples to identify representative solutions, quantitative inference tasks often demand the generation of hundreds or thousands of samples to estimate posterior moments and probabilities via Monte Carlo integration. The elevated cost currently constrains the practical implementation of DM-based strategies in such settings, especially when accurate uncertainty quantification is required.

Motivated by the needs of generative machine learning applications, efforts to reduce the computational cost of DMs have so far focused predominantly on reducing the cost of each NFE (e.g., pruning [25] and quantization [13]), and on reducing the number of NFEs required to generate each sample (e.g., via distillation [20] and improved numerical schemes [22]). In contrast, to the best of our knowledge, the potential for reducing the computational cost of DM-based Bayesian inversion by optimizing NFEs for Monte Carlo integration remains unexplored. This paper presents a new strategy to significantly reduce the cost of Monte Carlo integration in DM-based Bayesian inversion by leveraging Multilevel Monte Carlo (MLMC) [5, 6]. The proposed MLMC method is applicable to any DM, allowing it to be integrated with any of the aforementioned strategies to enhance the computational efficiency of posterior sampling and Bayesian computation through DMs.

# 2 Proposed Multilevel Monte Carlo approach
### 2.1 Notation and problem statement

We consider the estimation of an unknown high-dimensional quantity of interest $x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ from some observed data $y \in \mathbb{R}^{m}$. We formulate the problem in the Bayesian statistical framework and model $x$ as a realisation of a random variable $X$ taking values in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$, and the observation $y$ as a realisation of an $\mathbb{R}^{m}$-valued random variable that, conditional on $X=x$, has distribution

$$
Y \sim \mathcal{P}(\mathcal{A}(x))
$$

where the operator $\mathcal{A}: \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{m}$ encodes deterministic aspects of the observation model, and $\mathcal{P}$ models stochastic aspects such as measurement noise. The forward model (1) includes, for example, the widely used linear Gaussian observation model

$$
y=\mathcal{A} x+\eta
$$

where $\mathcal{A} \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times n}$ (often with $m<n$ ), and the additive perturbation $\eta$ is a realisation of zero-mean Gaussian noise with covariance $\sigma^{2} \mathbb{I}_{n}$ for $\sigma^{2} \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$and $\mathbb{I}_{n} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times n}$ being the identity matrix.

Additional information about the solution is introduced by specifying the prior distribution of $X$, whose density we henceforth denote by $\pi(\cdot)$. Observed and prior information are then combined by using Bayes' theorem to derive the posterior distribution for $X$ given the observation $Y=y$, with density denoted by $p(\cdot \mid y)$ satisfying

$$
p(x \mid y)=\frac{\mathcal{L}(y \mid x) \pi(x)}{\mathcal{E}(y)}
$$

for all $x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$, where $\mathcal{L}$ is the likelihood function associated to the statistical forward model (1) and $\mathcal{E}(y)$ is the data evidence which is defined so that the posterior density integrates to 1 .

As mentioned previously, we consider a purely data-driven scenario in which a DM has been trained to draw (approximate) posterior samples. This could be a DM trained on a dataset $\left\{x^{(i)}, y^{(i)}\right\}_{i=1}^{N}$ from the joint distribution of $(X, Y)[18]$, or alternatively by using a sample $\left\{x^{(i)}\right\}_{i=1}^{N}$ together with the likelihood $\mathcal{L}$ to design a so-called "guidance" term (see, e.g., $[4,11]$ ).

# 2.2 Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models 

DMs can be formulated in various forms. For presentation clarity, we present the proposed MLMC approach by using Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models (DDPMs), a powerful class of DMs capable of generating approximate samples from arbitrary distributions. DDPMs have appeared in various forms and iterations since their first formulation in [21]. DDPMs may be formulated directly as a finite sequence of noising kernels (each adding a discrete quantity of noise, hence here called discrete DDPMs) or as numerical approximations of a continuous time Stochastic Differential Equation (SDE, see Supplementary Material). For the purposes of illustration, we select the discrete formulation of e.g. $[9,23,21,22,11]$ since it is extendable to non-Markovian models such as DDIM [22] and it aligns more closely with the models used for our experiments in Section 3. Recalling that our goal is to sample from the posterior, with density $p(\cdot \mid y)$, for $X$ given the observation $Y=y$, we construct a sequence of "states" $\left\{X_{i}\right\}_{i=0}^{T}$ with $X_{0}=X$ and seek samples from the augmented posterior of $\left(X_{0}, \ldots, X_{T}\right)$ given $Y=y$, which admits the desired posterior as marginal. This joint posterior has density $p_{0: T}(\ldots \mid y)$, which we decompose as

$$
p_{0: T}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{T} \mid y\right)=\left(\prod_{t=1}^{T} \widehat{\mathcal{H}}_{t-1}\left(x_{t-1} \mid x_{t}, y\right)\right) p_{T}\left(x_{T} \mid y\right)
$$

for given reverse transition kernels $\left(\widehat{\mathcal{H}}_{t}\right)_{t=0}^{T-1}$ and posterior density $p_{T}(\cdot \mid y)$ of the final state $X_{T}$.
Starting with the posterior of the final state, we capture several different constructions by setting $p_{T}(x \mid y)=\phi_{n}\left(x ;\left(\mathbb{I}_{n}-\mathbb{M}\right) y, \mathbb{M}\right)^{1}$ for some binary diagonal matrix $\mathbb{M}$, which could potentially be degenerate. The choice of $\mathbb{M}$ controls the dependence of the final state on the observation $y$. We consider three cases that are frequently encountered in the literature:

1. $\mathbb{M}=\mathbb{I}_{n}$, so that $p_{T}(\cdot \mid y)=\phi_{n}(\cdot)$, i.e., $X_{T}$ is a standard Gaussian independent of the observation, see, e.g., Section 3.1. This choice can be motivated by relating $X_{T}$ to the input $X_{0}$ via

$$
p_{T}\left(x_{T} \mid y\right)=\frac{1}{\mathcal{E}(y)} \int K_{T ; 0}\left(x_{T} \mid x_{0}\right) \mathcal{L}\left(y \mid x_{0}, x_{T}\right) \pi\left(x_{0}\right) d x_{0}
$$

where $\mathcal{E}(\cdot)$ is the data evidence and $K_{T ; 0}$ is the forward transition kernel from the input $X_{0}$ to the final state $X_{T}$. As we shall shortly see, in DMs the transition kernel $K_{T ; 0}$ is chosen

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ We denote the standard normal density in $n$ dimensions by $\phi_{n}(\cdot)$ and use the notation $\phi_{n}(x ; \mu, \Sigma)=\phi_{n}\left(\Sigma^{-1 / 2}(x-\right.$ $\mu)$ ) for $\mu, x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}, \Sigma \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times n}$, as the normal density with mean $\mu$ and covariance matrix $\Sigma$.

to be a standard Gaussian independent of the value of the input, i.e., $K_{T ; 0}\left(\cdot \mid x_{0}\right)=\phi_{n}(\cdot)$. Then we choose the likelihood as $\mathcal{L}\left(\cdot \mid x_{0}, x_{T}\right)=\mathcal{L}\left(\cdot \mid x_{0}\right)$. That is, the observation likelihood is independent of the final state given the input, to yield $p_{T}(\cdot \mid y)=\phi_{n}(\cdot)$.
2. $\mathbb{M}=0$, i.e., we assume that for a given input, $X_{T}=Y$ and hence we formally take $p_{T}(\cdot \mid y)=$ $\delta_{y}(\cdot)$, see, e.g., Section 3.2. Here again the transition kernel $K_{T ; 0}\left(\cdot \mid x_{0}\right)$ is standard Gaussian, hence this choice models the case when the conditional density of $Y$ given $X_{0}$ is standard Gaussian.
3. If $\mathbb{M}$ is a binary diagonal matrix with some ones and zeros on the diagonal, then the final state will depend on only parts of the observation, see, e.g., Section 3.3. Typically, the same masking matrix, $\mathbb{M}$, is used to define the transition kernels below, however we will omit this detail in the following for clarity of exposition.

Turning to the choice of transition kernels, one first considers a Gaussian, Markovian forward process, for $X_{t}$ given $X_{t-1}$, whose transition density is

$$
K_{t}\left(x \mid x_{t-1}\right)=\phi_{n}\left(x ; \sqrt{\frac{\gamma_{t}}{\gamma_{t-1}}} x_{t-1},\left(1-\frac{\gamma_{t}}{\gamma_{t-1}}\right) \mathbb{I}_{n}\right)
$$

for $x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ and where $1=\gamma_{0}>\gamma_{1}>\ldots>\gamma_{T}>0$. This choice gives rise to a conditional distribution for $X_{t}$ given the input, $X_{0}$, whose density is

$$
K_{t ; 0}\left(x \mid x_{0}\right)=\phi_{n}\left(x ; \sqrt{\gamma_{t}} x_{0},\left(1-\gamma_{t}\right) \mathbb{I}_{n}\right), \quad 1 \leq t \leq T
$$

Note that $K_{T ; 0}\left(\cdot \mid x_{0}\right) \rightarrow \phi_{n}(\cdot)$ when $\gamma_{T} \rightarrow 0$ as mentioned above. Such Gaussian choices lead to tractable models for training and inference $[11,22]$.

We determine the reverse transition kernel by further conditioning on the input, $X_{0}$ and assuming that, given $X_{0}$ and $X_{t}$, intermediate states are independent of the observation $Y$, i.e.,

$$
\widehat{\mathcal{U}}_{t-1}\left(x \mid x_{t}, y\right)=\int \mathcal{U}_{t-1 ; 0, t}\left(x \mid x_{0}, x_{t}\right) \widehat{\mathcal{U}}_{0 ; t}\left(x_{0} \mid x_{t}, y\right) d x_{0}
$$

The reverse transition kernels $\mathcal{U}_{t-1 ; 0, t}\left(\cdot \mid x_{0}, x_{t}\right)=\phi_{n}\left(\cdot, \mu_{t-1 ; 0, t}, \sigma_{t-1 ; 0, t}^{2} \mathbb{I}_{n}\right)$ where, denoting $\Gamma_{t}=$ $\left(1-\gamma_{t}\right),[9]$

$$
\mu_{t-1 ; 0, t}\left(x_{0}, x_{t}\right)=\sqrt{\frac{\gamma_{t}}{\gamma_{t-1}}} \frac{\Gamma_{t-1}}{\Gamma_{t}}\left(x_{t}-\sqrt{\gamma_{t}} x_{0}\right)+\sqrt{\gamma_{t-1}} x_{0}, \quad \sigma_{t-1 ; 0, t}^{2}=\frac{\Gamma_{t-1}}{\Gamma_{t}}\left(1-\frac{\gamma_{t}}{\gamma_{t-1}}\right)
$$

The only remaining unknown is the reverse transition kernel $\widehat{\mathcal{U}}_{0 ; t}\left(\cdot \mid x_{t}, y\right)$, for the input, $X_{0}$, conditioned on the observation and state $X_{t}$. Following [24], we note that the score function, $\nabla \log K_{t ; 0}\left(\cdot \mid x_{0}\right)$, satisfies $\nabla \log K_{t ; 0}\left(x \mid x_{0}\right)=\left(\sqrt{\gamma_{t}} x_{0}-x\right) / \Gamma_{t}$ and use a neural network $s_{\theta}$ with parameters $\theta$ to approximate the score $s_{\theta}(x, y, t ; \theta) \approx \nabla \log K_{t ; 0}\left(x \mid x_{0}\right)$. Thus we obtain an estimate of $x_{0}$ depending on the given state $x_{t}$ and the observation, $y$,

$$
x_{0}\left(x_{t}, y, t ; \theta\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\gamma_{t}}}\left(x_{t}+\Gamma_{t} s_{\theta}\left(x_{t}, y, t\right)\right)
$$

and replace the kernel $\widehat{\mathcal{U}}_{0 ; t}\left(\cdot \mid x_{t}, y\right)$ with a point mass at that estimate, which when substituted back in (7) yields a Gaussian conditional, reverse transition kernel $\widehat{\mathcal{U}}_{t-1}\left(x \mid x_{t}, y\right)$. Note that we introduce

a dependence of $s_{\theta}$ on $y$ since we want to approximate the reverse transition kernel $\widehat{\mathcal{U}}_{0 ; t}\left(\cdot \mid x_{t}, y\right)$, which in general depends on the observation. Alternative parametrisations, or indeed directly approximating $x_{0}$ are possible [9, 22, 19]. As $s_{\theta}$ approximates $\nabla \log K_{t ; 0}\left(x \mid x_{0}\right)$, (depending on the forward transition kernel), it is not suitable to use in reverse, i.e, starting from $X_{T}$, except in the specific case where the reverse process is also approximately Gaussian, which holds in the limit of a continuous process $\gamma_{t} \approx \gamma_{t-1}$ [21]. Therefore, producing accurate samples typically requires using a large number of intermediate steps. In particular, one generates approximate samples $\left(x_{t}\right)_{t=0}^{T-1}$ starting from $X_{T} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\left(\mathbb{I}_{n}-\mathbb{M}\right) y, \mathbb{M}\right)$, recursively as follows

$$
x_{t-1}=\sqrt{\frac{\gamma_{t-1}}{\gamma_{t}}} x_{t}-\sqrt{\frac{\gamma_{t}}{\gamma_{t-1}}}\left(\Gamma_{t-1}-\frac{\gamma_{t-1}}{\gamma_{t}} \Gamma_{t}\right) s_{\theta}\left(x_{t}, y, t\right)+\sqrt{\frac{\Gamma_{t-1}}{\Gamma_{t}}\left(1-\frac{\gamma_{t}}{\gamma_{t-1}}\right)} \xi_{t}
$$

where $\xi_{t} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0, \mathbb{I}_{n}\right)$. At the end, $x_{0}$ will be an approximate sample from the target posterior $p(\cdot \mid y)$. In practice, one incurs four sources of errors:

Truncation Error Let $p_{t}(\cdot \mid y)$ be the marginal density of $X_{t}$ given $Y=y$. The target posterior, $p(\cdot \mid y)=p_{0}(\cdot \mid y)$, is in general not supported on all of $\mathbb{R}^{n}$, whereas the Gaussian kernels $\mathcal{H}_{t}\left(\cdot \mid x_{t}, y\right)$ and hence the densities, $p_{t}(\cdot \mid y)$, are. In particular, the different supports of $p_{0}(\cdot \mid y)$ and $p_{1}(\cdot \mid y)$ manifest in the fact that $s_{\theta}(x, t, y)$ will blow up as $t \rightarrow 0$, which causes numerical instability as $t \rightarrow 0$ [24]. In practice, one either takes $x_{1}$ as an approximate sample from $p_{0}(\cdot \mid y)$ or uses a Gaussian approximation of the reverse transition kernel which does not use $s_{\theta}$, i.e., $\mathcal{H}_{0}\left(\cdot \mid x_{1}\right)=$ $\phi_{n}\left(\cdot ; \sqrt{1 / \gamma_{1}} x_{1}, \sigma_{1}^{2}\right)$, for a constant $\sigma_{1} \geq 0[22,23]$. In either case one incurs a 'truncation error'. In other models, (e.g. [19]) altering the final step is not necessary, but one still implicitly assumes that a Gaussian posterior $p_{0}(\cdot \mid y)$ and thus incorporates the same error.

Finite-Time Error Note that for the forward process (6), by choosing a sufficiently rapidly decreasing sequence with $\lim _{t \rightarrow T} \gamma_{t}=0$, one obtains $K_{T ; 0}\left(\cdot \mid x_{0}\right) \rightarrow \phi_{n}(\cdot)$, and sampling the final state, $X_{T}$, can be done easily. However, since one is going to reverse the process, one does not wish to have the difference between consecutive noise levels for the reverse process $\gamma_{t-1} / \gamma_{t}$ be too large, as this makes sampling the states too difficult, see (10) and 'Discretization Error' below. As a consequence, $\gamma_{t} / \gamma_{t-1}>0$ cannot be too small and so with a finite number of steps, one can only have $0<\gamma_{T}=\prod_{t=1}^{T} \gamma_{t} / \gamma_{t-1}$. In this case, sampling $X_{T}$ as standard Gaussian induces an error, which we call a 'finite-time' approximation error, as this is the same error that is incurred when diffusion models are obtained as finite-time approximations of the stationary solution of an SDE in continuous time.

Model Error The parameters $\theta$ of the mapping $s_{\theta}$ are typically obtained by relying on the forward process (6) and a dataset of input/observation pairs $\left\{x_{0}^{(i)}, y^{(i)}\right\}_{i=1}^{N}$, where the observations $y^{(i)}$ are given or generated from $x_{0}^{(i)}$ according to (1). In this case, recalling (9), one can obtain $\theta$ as

$$
\arg \min _{\theta} \frac{1}{N|\mathcal{T}|} \sum_{t \in \mathcal{T}} \sum_{i=1}^{N}\left\|s_{\theta}\left(x_{t}^{(i)}, t, y^{(i)}\right)+\Gamma_{t}^{-1}\left(x_{t}^{(i)}-\sqrt{\gamma_{t}} x_{0}^{(i)}\right)\right\|^{2}
$$

where $\mathcal{T}$ is a uniformly sampled set, with repetition, from $\{0,1, \ldots, T\}$.
Here, when $\mathbb{M}=\mathbb{I}_{n}, x_{t}^{(i)}$ may be sampled given $x_{0}^{(i)}$ via the transition kernel $K_{t ; 0}\left(\cdot \mid x_{0}^{(i)}\right)$ in (6), independently of the observation, $y$; in particular $x_{T}^{(i)}$ given $x_{0}^{(i)}$ will be approximately standard Gaussian. Alternatively, when $\mathbb{M}=0$, and following [14], one may instead sample $x_{t}^{(i)}$ using the

reverse transition kernel $\mathcal{H}_{t ; 0, T}\left(\cdot \mid x_{0}, x_{T}\right)=\phi_{n}\left(\cdot, \mu_{t ; 0, T}, \sigma_{t ; 0, T}^{2} \mathbb{\xi}_{n}\right)^{2}$ and setting $x_{T}^{(i)}=y^{(i)}$. In this case, $s_{\theta}$ would not need to directly depend on the observation $y$, since for $t=T$ we have $x_{T}=y$ and for $t<T$ the states $x_{t}$ depend on $x_{T}=y$.
In either case, the error incurred by using the approximate $x_{0}$, as a function of $s_{\theta}$, in place of the true $x_{0}$ shall be called the 'model error'.

Discretization Error Since one samples via (10), it is possible to 'skip' steps and generate $x_{t-2}$ directly from $x_{t}$ reducing the NFEs by 1 , or by $T / 2$ if every other step is skipped. The reverse kernel $\mathcal{H}_{t-2 ; t, 0}\left(\cdot \mid x_{t}, x_{0}\right)$ is derived via the decomposition

$$
\mathcal{H}_{t-2 ; 0, t}\left(x \mid x_{0}, x_{t}\right)=\int \mathcal{H}_{t-1 ; 0, t}\left(x_{t-1} \mid x_{0}, x_{t}\right) \mathcal{H}_{t-2 ; 0, t-1}\left(x \mid x_{0}, x_{t-1}\right) d x_{t-1}
$$

which, using [2, p.93], yields $\mathcal{H}_{t-2 ; 0, t}\left(\cdot \mid x_{t}, x_{0}\right)=\phi_{n}\left(\cdot ; \mu_{t-2 ; 0, t}, \sigma_{t-2 ; 0, t}^{2}\right)$ and an update of the same form as (8). In particular,

$$
\sigma_{t-2 ; 0, t}=\sigma_{t-2 ; 0, t-1}^{2}+\frac{\gamma_{t-1}}{\gamma_{t-2}} \frac{\Gamma_{t-2}^{2}}{\Gamma_{t-1}^{2}} \sigma_{t-1 ; 0, t}^{2}=\frac{\Gamma_{t-2}}{\Gamma_{t}}\left(1-\frac{\gamma_{t}}{\gamma_{t-2}}\right)
$$

Similarly, for any integer $M>1$,

$$
\sigma_{t-M ; 0, t}^{2}=\sigma_{t-M ; 0, t-M+1}^{2}+\frac{\gamma_{t-M+1}}{\gamma_{t-M}} \frac{\Gamma_{t-M}^{2}}{\Gamma_{t-M+1}^{2}} \sigma_{t-M+1 ; 0, t}^{2}=\frac{\Gamma_{t-M}}{\Gamma_{t}}\left(1-\frac{\gamma_{t}}{\gamma_{t-M}}\right)
$$

where the last equality follows by induction. Sampling would be implemented iteratively via an update of the same form as (10), with a reduced number of steps,

$$
x_{t-M}=\sqrt{\frac{\gamma_{t-M}}{\gamma_{t}}} x_{t}-\sqrt{\frac{\gamma_{t}}{\gamma_{t-M}}}\left(\Gamma_{t-M}-\frac{\gamma_{t-M}}{\gamma_{t}} \Gamma_{t}\right) s_{\theta}\left(x_{t}, t, y\right)+\sqrt{\frac{\Gamma_{t-M}}{\Gamma_{t}}\left(1-\frac{\gamma_{t}}{\gamma_{t-M}}\right)} \xi_{t}
$$

where $\xi_{t} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0, \mathbb{I}_{n}\right)$. While skipping steps reduces the overall NFEs and hence the overall cost of sampling, it also introduces the error which we call the discretization error; motivated again by the induced error when diffusion models are obtained via a time discretisation of an SDE in continuous time. To see the source of this error in our discrete setting, recall that we approximate the reverse transition kernel $\widetilde{\mathcal{H}}_{0 ; t}\left(\cdot, \mid x_{t}, y\right)$ in (7) by a point mass function at an estimate of $x_{0}$, which leads to a Gaussian approximation of the reverse transition kernel, $\widetilde{\mathcal{H}}_{t-1}\left(x \mid x_{t}, y\right)$. Hence, we expect that when skipping steps, the reverse transition kernel $\widetilde{\mathcal{H}}_{t-M}\left(x \mid x_{t}, y\right)$ will be further away from a Gaussian compared to $\widetilde{\mathcal{H}}_{t-1}\left(x \mid x_{t}, y\right)$ [21].
For our purposes then, the neural network approximating the score and the truncation parameter error are taken to be fixed; the effect of finite-time error is negligible in practice compared to the other error sources ${ }^{3}$ [1]. Thus the most significant error, and the one we are concerned with in this

    $$

    $$

work, is the discretisation error. We note that modifications to the noise or score function scaling in (10), such as DDIM [22], and concatenating together several steps as described above, have been used to accelerate sample generation (whilst still training on a finer, possibly continuous time mesh). As has been emphasised, this is because, while $10^{3}$ steps produce accurate samples, generating them is too slow for most Bayesian computation applications. The power of the proposed MLMC-based acceleration is that it combines the rapidity of cheap samples with the precision of expensive ones when computing Monte Carlo averages, since, due to the telescoping structure of MLMC, errors that are made at coarser discretisation levels are cancelled when a new level is introduced.

# 2.3 Multilevel Monte Carlo 

Conventional Monte Carlo averaging delivers estimates of (analytically intractable) expectations of some function $f$ of a random variable $X$, with probability density $p(\cdot)$, via the sum

$$
\mathbb{E}[f(X)]=\int f(x) p(x) d x \approx N^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{N} f\left(x^{(i)}\right)
$$

where $x^{(i)}$ are independent realisation of $X$ and where the integral is over the domain of $X$. The variance of the estimate is then $N^{-1} \mathbb{V}[f(X)]=N^{-1} \mathbb{E}\left[\|f(X)-\mathbb{E}[f(X)]\|^{2}\right]$. As a consequence, obtaining an estimate with root mean-square error $\varepsilon$ requires $N=\mathcal{O}\left(\varepsilon^{-2}\right)$ samples, which may be prohibitive if sample generation is costly. This is precisely the case with DMs for Bayesian inversion in computational imaging, where one may require $10^{3}$ NFEs per sample $x^{(i)}$ to obtain accurate inferences [24]. However, whilst accurate samples may require $10^{3}$ NFEs or more, in many cases one can obtain meaningful inferences with as little as 50 NFEs (see, e.g., Fig. 2). MLMC [6] seeks to exploit this by appropriately combining samples with coarse resolution with samples with fine resolution, while maintaining the overall accuracy of the estimate, at a fraction of the cost. More concretely, consider approximations of $X$, denoted by $\left\{\widehat{X}_{\ell}\right\}_{\ell=0,1 \ldots, L^{4}}$, where the resolution and the cost of generating a sample of $\widehat{X}_{\ell}$, e.g., the number of NFEs, increase with $\ell$. For example, take that a sample of $\widehat{X}_{L}$ requires $10^{3}$ NFEs, while a sample of $\widehat{X}_{0}$ requires 50 NFEs, with intermediate values of $\ell$ requiring an increasing sequence of NFEs per sample.

We seek to approximate the expectation $\mathbb{E}[f(X)]$. One could do this in a similar fashion as in (14) only using samples $\widehat{x}_{L}^{(i)}$ of $\widehat{X}_{L}$ for sufficiently large $L$. Alternatively, one may build an estimator, $Y$, for $\mathbb{E}\left[f\left(\widehat{X}_{L}\right)\right]$ using the identity

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[f\left(\widehat{X}_{L}\right)\right] & =\mathbb{E}\left[f\left(\widehat{X}_{0}\right)\right]+\sum_{\ell=1}^{L} \mathbb{E}\left[f\left(\widehat{X}_{\ell}\right)-f\left(\widehat{X}_{\ell-1}\right)\right] \\
& \approx N_{0}^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{N_{\ell}} f\left(\widehat{x}_{0}^{(0, i)}\right)+\sum_{\ell=1}^{L} N_{\ell}^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{N_{\ell}}\left[f\left(\widehat{x}_{\ell}^{(\ell, i)}\right)-f\left(\widehat{x}_{\ell-1}^{(\ell, i)}\right)\right] \\
& \equiv Y_{0}+\sum_{\ell=1}^{L} Y_{\ell} \equiv Y
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, $\left\{\widehat{x}_{\ell}^{(\ell, i)}, \widehat{x}_{\ell-1}^{(\ell, i)}\right\}_{\ell, i}$ are correlated samples of $\left\{\widehat{X}_{\ell}, \widehat{X}_{\ell-1}\right\}$. This correlation is crucial so that the variance of the difference $f\left(\widehat{X}_{\ell}\right)-f\left(\widehat{X}_{\ell-1}\right)$ gets smaller, hence requiring fewer samples, as $\ell$ increases and the cost of sampling this difference increases. Denoting the cost per sample and variance of

[^0]:    ${ }^{4}$ We note the slight abuse of notation. In the previous section, $\left\{X_{i}\right\}_{i=0}^{T}$ denoted the states of the diffusion model, starting with $X_{0}=X$. In the current section, $\left\{\widehat{X}_{\ell}\right\}_{\ell=0}^{L}$ denote approximations of $X$.

Minimizing the total cost subject to $V[Y]<\varepsilon^{2} / 2$ yields the optimal number of samples

$$
N_{\ell} \approx 2 \varepsilon^{-2} \sqrt{V_{\ell} C_{\ell}^{-1}}\left(\sum_{\ell=0}^{L} \sqrt{V_{\ell} C_{\ell}}\right)
$$

and the optimal total cost $C \approx \varepsilon^{-2}\left(\sum_{\ell=0}^{L} \sqrt{V_{\ell} C_{\ell}}\right)^{2}[6]$. Hence the total cost is proportional to

$$
\begin{cases}\varepsilon^{-2} V_{0} C_{0} & \text { if } V_{\ell} C_{\ell} \text { decreases sufficiently fast } \\ \varepsilon^{-2} L^{2} & \text { if } V_{\ell} C_{\ell} \approx \text { constant } \\ \varepsilon^{-2} V_{L} C_{L} & \text { if } V_{\ell} C_{\ell} \text { increases sufficiently fast. }\end{cases}
$$

For example, compare the first case to the total cost of standard Monte Carlo sampling of $\mathbb{E}\left[f\left(\widehat{X}_{L}\right)\right]$ which is $\propto \varepsilon^{-2} \mathbb{V}\left[f\left(\widehat{X}_{L}\right)\right] C_{L}$. Since $C_{0} \ll C_{L}$ and typically $V_{0} \approx \mathbb{V}\left[f\left(\widehat{X}_{L}\right)\right]$ - as we do not expect a significant dependence of variance of the quantity on the approximation if the used random variables are appropriately scaled - the cost of MLMC is significantly smaller.

In sample generation using DMs, the sample cost and accuracy increases as the number of time steps, $T$, in (4) increases, which is equivalent to the NFEs. We set the number of time steps for $\widehat{X}_{\ell}$ to be $T_{0} M^{\ell}$ for some integers $T_{0}, M>1$, the cost for generating a sample of $f\left(\widehat{X}_{\ell}\right)-f\left(\widehat{X}_{\ell-1}\right)$ at each level $\ell$ is then $C_{\ell}=C_{0}\left(M^{\ell}+M^{\ell-1}\right)=C_{0}\left(1+M^{-1}\right) M^{\ell}<2 C_{0} M^{\ell}$, for a constant $C_{0}$. In practice, we additionally have, or assume, that $V_{\ell} \propto M^{-\beta \ell}$ and $\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[f(X)-f\left(\widehat{X}_{\ell}\right)\right]\right\| \propto M^{-\alpha \ell}$ for some $\alpha, \beta>0$. Given that the MSE is

$$
\mathrm{MSE}=\mathbb{E}\left[\|Y-\mathbb{E}[f(X)]\|^{2}\right]=\mathbb{V}[Y]+\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[f\left(\widehat{X}_{L}\right)-f(X)\right]\right\|^{2}
$$

we impose $\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[f\left(\widehat{X}_{L}\right)-f(X)\right]\right\|^{2} \leq \varepsilon^{2} / 2$ yielding $L \approx \frac{-1}{\alpha}\left|\log _{M}(\varepsilon / 2)\right|$, up to a constant. Substituting the value of $L$ and the bounds of $\left\{C_{\ell}, V_{\ell}\right\}_{\ell=0}^{L}$ in the total costs, we arrive at $[6]$

$$
C_{\mathrm{MLMC}} \lesssim V_{0} C_{0} \varepsilon^{-2} \begin{cases}1 & 1<\beta \\ \left|\log _{M}(\varepsilon)\right|^{2} & 1=\beta \\ \varepsilon^{(\beta-1) / \alpha}, & 1>\beta\end{cases}
$$

Hence, comparing the cost of classical Monte Carlo estimators of $\mathbb{E}[f(X)]$ for the same accuracy, which is of order $\varepsilon^{-2-1 / \alpha}$, MLMC offers significant savings with the best case being when $\beta>1$.

An algorithm for MLMC A heuristic algorithm which iteratively increments $\left\{N_{\ell}\right\}_{\ell=0}^{L}$ and $L$ to reduce the bias and variance below a given tolerance is shown in Algorithm 1, see also [6]. The bias estimate may be taken as $\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[Y-f\left(\widehat{X}_{L}\right)\right]\right\| \approx\left\|Y_{L}\right\| /\left(M^{\alpha}-1\right)$, see $[6]$.
Remark 1 (Strategies for estimating the bias) When estimating the bias, we typically utilise $Y_{L-1}$ as well as $Y_{L}$, as $N_{\ell}$ decreases with $\ell$, and hence the calculation of $Y_{L}$ may use fewer samples and be less stable than the calculation of $Y_{L-1}$. For example, we may check that $\max \left(\left\|Y_{L-1}\right\| M^{-\alpha},\left\|Y_{L}\right\|\right) /\left(M^{\alpha}-\right.$ 1). Similarly, since one has access to $\alpha, \beta$ (via linear regression of $V_{\ell}$ and $\left\|Y_{\ell}\right\|$ or theoretical analysis), one may use the models $V_{\ell} \propto M^{-\beta \ell},\left\|Y_{\ell}\right\| \propto M^{-\alpha \ell}$ to prevent underestimation of the variance and bias [6]. Finally, noting that the norm $\left\|Y_{\ell}\right\|$ is a biased estimator of $\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[f\left(\widehat{X}_{\ell}\right)-f\left(\widehat{X}_{\ell-1}\right)\right]\right\|$, we have found that debiasing the estimator produces better results when the number of samples is small. We do this by iteratively scaling the biased estimate $\left\|Y_{\ell}\right\|$ by the factor $\left(1+N_{\ell}^{-1} V_{\ell} /\left\|Y_{\ell}\right\|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}$ and recomputing $V_{\ell}$ (which depends on $Y_{\ell}$ ) until the estimate converges.

Choice of starting level, $\ell_{0}$ The starting value $\ell_{0}$ one uses can be determined via Eq. (3.6) in $[7]$

$$
V_{1} \leq \frac{\left(\sqrt{\mathbb{V}\left[f\left(\tilde{X}_{1}\right)\right] M}-\sqrt{\mathbb{V}\left[f\left(\tilde{X}_{0}\right)\right]}\right)^{2}}{(1+M)}
$$

where one generates samples to estimate $V_{1}=\mathbb{V}\left[f\left(\tilde{X}_{1}\right)-f\left(\tilde{X}_{0}\right)\right]$ and $\mathbb{V}\left[f\left(\tilde{X}_{1}\right)\right]$ with $M^{\ell_{0}+1}$ steps, and $\mathbb{V}\left[f\left(\tilde{X}_{0}\right)\right]$ with $M^{\ell_{0}}$ steps. To maximise the efficiency of MLMC one increases $\ell_{0}$ until one fulfills (19).

# 2.4 Sample Generation with Diffusion Models for MLMC 

In our setting, the MLMC samples which are used in Algorithm 1 are generated via DMs using (13) iteratively to give an correlated samples of $\left(\tilde{X}_{\ell}, \tilde{X}_{\ell-1}\right)$. Algorithm 2 details a single iteration to generate such samples. Given an approximation level, $\ell$, and starting from equal coarse and fine states $\tilde{x}_{\ell-1}=\tilde{x}_{\ell}$, sampled from a normal distribution, cf. Section 2.2, one updates this pair of states by iteratively calling Algorithm 2 a total of $M^{\ell-1}$ times.

For MLMC to have better computational efficiency than Monte Carlo, the correlation at each level $\ell$ between the samples $\tilde{X}_{\ell}$ and $\tilde{X}_{\ell-1}$ should be maximised. To accomplish this, one uses the same realisation of the Gaussian noise increments $\left(\xi_{t}\right)_{t=0}^{T}$ with two different discretisations to generate each sample [6]. In practice this is accomplished by summing the same set of Gaussian noise increments $\xi_{t}$ for the fine and coarse paths. However, this summing must be done in a weighted manner since from (12) it is clear that the variance of the added noise for a coarse step (assuming it is equivalent to two fine steps) is a weighted sum of the variances for the two fine steps - thus one may generate the coarse noise $\eta_{c}^{(t)}$ via two fine noise samples $\eta_{f}^{(t)}=\sigma_{t-1 ; 0, t} \xi_{t}$ using $\eta_{c}^{(t)}=\sqrt{\frac{\gamma_{t-1}}{\gamma_{t-2}} \frac{V_{t-2}}{\Gamma_{t-1}}} \eta_{f}^{(t)}+\eta_{f}^{(t-1)}$. Then, from (12) in the general case of $M$ fine steps to every coarse step, one updates $\eta_{c}^{(t)}$ according to Line 6 in Algorithm 2. $\eta_{c}^{(t)}$ is then maximally correlated with the fine path and has the correct scale. This is then used the reverse the coarse state in Line 11.

```
Algorithm 1 MLMC Algorithm
Input: \(\ell_{0}, N^{(0)}\)
    \(L \leftarrow \ell_{0}+2\)
    Set target samples to \(N^{(0)}\) for \(\ell_{0} \ldots L\)
    while extra samples required do
        Generate extra samples at each level
        Estimate \(V_{\ell},\left\|Y_{\ell}\right\|\) for \(\ell=\ell_{0} \ldots L\)
        Update required number of samples \(N_{\ell}\) for \(\ell=\ell_{0} \ldots L\) using (16)
        if bias larger than \(\varepsilon / \sqrt{2}\) then
            \(L \leftarrow L+1\)
            Estimate \(V_{L}\) and calculate \(N_{L}\)
        end if
    end while
```

# 3 Experiments 

We now demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed MLMC approach with three canonical inverse problems related to computational imaging: image denoising, image inpainting, and image superresolution. We have chosen these specific problems because they allow us to demonstrate the MLMC approach with three markedly different DM-based posterior sampling strategies that are representative of the main strategies studied in the literature ${ }^{5}$.

Since the quantitative and scientific imaging applications of interest rely strongly on the posterior mean estimator (i.e. minimum mean square error solution), the posterior covariance is a natural measure for uncertainty quantification. Unfortunately, computing the full posterior covariance is infeasible in imaging problems because of the high dimensionality involved. Therefore, to probe the posterior covariance, one typically performs a multiresolution analysis, first computing the marginal posterior variance of individual image pixels, and subsequently of groups of pixels of size $2 \times 2,4 \times 4, \ldots, 32 \times 32$ pixels [12]. One thus captures the uncertainty in image structures of different sizes and in different regions of the scene, and in a manner that is easy to visualize. Of all these uncertainty visualization maps, the map corresponding to the individual pixel scales is the most expensive to compute, as individual pixels exhibit higher variance than groups of multiple pixels. Hence, we choose to use the marginal second moment of the individual image pixels to measure the gain in computational efficiency of MLMC relative to the conventional MC approach. The quantity of interest is then simply $f(x)=x^{2}$ for $x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$, where the square of a vector is defined element-wise.

We compare MLMC to MC via the ratio of the MSEs when approximating the second moment for the same cost, defined as total number of NFEs. In all experiments we select the refinement factor between levels as $M=2$. Recall that the maximum level required, $L \approx-\log _{M}(\varepsilon) / \alpha$, is such that the bias be less than $\varepsilon / \sqrt{2}$. We therefore expect that, for a given $\varepsilon$, the efficiency gain of MLMC relative to MC to be greater the smaller $\alpha$. To obtain estimates of the coefficients $\alpha$ and $\beta$ we use estimates of $\left\|Y_{\ell}\right\|$ and $V_{\ell}$, respectively. These are also used to determine the starting

For our numerical study of MLMC, we use either $10^{3}$ (image super-resolution and inpainting experiments) or $10^{4}$ (image denoising experiment) samples at each level to obtain estimates of the sample variance $\left\{V_{\ell}\right\}_{\ell}$ and bias $\left\{Y_{\ell}\right\}_{\ell}$. Using these estimates, we verify our MLMC methods by checking whether the desired accuracy is indeed obtained, via

$$
\varepsilon_{\mathrm{est}}=\sqrt{\left\|Y_{L}\right\|^{2} /\left(M^{\alpha}-1\right)^{2}+\sum_{\ell=0}^{L} V_{\ell} / N_{\ell}}
$$

# 3.1 Experiment 1: Image super-resolution 

We first demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed approach in a Bayesian image super-resolution problem. In a manner akin to [19], we consider (2) in the noiseless setting, $\eta=0$, and thus $y=\mathcal{A} x$, $\mathcal{A} \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times n}$. We focus on the $16 \times 16 \rightarrow 128 \times 128$ case, where $y$ is an image of size $16 \times 16$ pixels obtained by down-sampling a high-resolution image $x$ of size $128 \times 128$ pixels (see Fig. 1a). This is a challenging ill-posed inverse problem, as the dimension of $y$ is dramatically smaller than the dimension of $x$, leading to significance posterior uncertainty. Fig. 1a depicts a sample from the posterior distribution $p(\cdot \mid y)$, as generated by the machine-learning-based SR3 model ${ }^{6}$ with 2048 steps [19]. The SR3 model is a conditional DM obtained by training a network $s_{\theta}(x, t, y)$ specialised for image superresolution, with the loss function (11) and a dataset of paired high $\left(x_{0}\right)$ and low $(y)$ resolution images $\left\{x_{0}^{(i)}, y^{(i)}\right\}_{i=1}^{N}$. Note that in this case one has $\mathbb{M}=0$ and so $p_{T}(x \mid y)=\phi_{n}\left(x ; 0, \mathbb{I}_{n}\right)$ (see Item 1 in Section 2.2). Therefore, for sampling from the posterior $p(\cdot \mid y)$ one proceeds to generate samples via (10) with $x_{T} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0, \mathbb{I}_{n}\right)$.

To illustrate the computational efficiency of MLMC relative to the conventional MC approach, we use MLMC to estimate the marginal second moment of each image pixel to various degrees of precision. Results are shown in Fig. 3a, where one sees that MLMC substantially outperforms MC (e.g., to obtain a precision of 0.0013 , corresponding to $0.1 \%$ of the pixel dynamic range, it is $4 \times$ more efficient to use MLMC rather than MC, where one uses $2^{10}=512$ NFEs at the finest level). The variance in the upper left plot is especially large for small $\ell$ since the sampler starts from $\mathcal{N}(0, I)$; hence with a few steps, this noise is not removed and thus the variance over a set of samples is large. Correspondingly, correlation between the fine and coarse paths is null and so the variance of the difference $f\left(\widehat{X}_{\ell}\right)-f\left(\widehat{X}_{\ell-1}\right)$ is essentially $\mathbb{V}\left[f\left(\widehat{X}_{\ell}\right)\right]+\mathbb{V}\left[f\left(\widehat{X}_{\ell-1}\right)\right]$. As a consequence, the condition (19) is not satisfied for a number of steps less than 32 . Turning to the upper-right plot, one has $\alpha=0.7$. Fig. 2 shows example samples at various levels.

# 3.2 Experiment 2: Image denoising 

We now study the Gaussian image denoising problem $y=x_{0}+\sigma_{y} \eta$ with $\eta \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0, \mathbb{I}_{n}\right)$, resulting from (2) with $\mathcal{A}=\mathbb{I}_{n}$. We consider a high noise level $\sigma_{y}=0.8$ (image pixels take values in the range $[-1,1]$ ), so there is significant posterior uncertainty as a result. DM-based Bayesian methods for this problem leverage the fact that $y$ is a noisy version of $x_{0}$, so one may scale $y$ such that the noise level corresponds to that of the solution at time $T$ of the forward noising process (6) as detailed in [11, Appendix B]. We thus obtain

$$
y^{\dagger}=\sqrt{\gamma_{T}} y=\sqrt{\gamma_{T}} x_{0}+\sqrt{\gamma_{T}} \sigma_{y} \eta
$$

so $\gamma_{T}=\left(1+\sigma_{y}^{2}\right)^{-1}$. To perform Bayesian computation, one may generate approximate samples from the posterior distribution $p(\cdot \mid y)$ via the reverse process (10) with $p_{T}(\cdot \mid y)=\delta_{y^{\dagger}}(\cdot)^{T}$. In this case, the mapping $s_{\theta}$ is independent of $y$, since $\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}_{t-1}\left(\cdot \mid x_{t}, y\right)$ is independent of $y$ ( $y$ is always noisier than $x_{t}$ for $t<T$ ). In our Bayesian imaging denoising experiment, $s_{\theta}$ is a neural network specialised for image denoising, trained on the CIFAR10 data by using a VPSDE formulation ${ }^{8}$. Fig. 1b presents an example of a clean CIFAR10 image and its noisy observation, $y$, with $\sigma_{y}=0.8$, together with a posterior sample as generated by the DM of [24] with 2048 steps.

We now estimate the marginal second moment of each image pixel to various precisions via MLMC and MC (see Fig. 3b). MLMC substantially outperforms MC (e.g., to obtain a precision of 0.001 , corresponding to $0.1 \%$ of the pixel dynamic range, it is roughly $7 \times$ more efficient to use MLMC rather than MC). The variance plot in the upper left shows that the variance increases as $\ell$ increases, in contrast to the super-resolution problem where we observed a large variance for small $\ell$. This stems from the fact that in this experiment the initial condition is fixed to the observation. In addition, the sampling scheme (10) does not add noise in the final step, hence the variance is low when $\ell$ is small.

### 3.3 Experiment 3: Image inpainting

We now consider a Bayesian image inpainting experiment, where one seeks to perform inference on an unobserved region within the interior of an image. In this experiment $y=\left(\mathbb{I}_{n}-\mathbb{M}\right) x$, a form of (2) with $\mathcal{A}=\left(\mathbb{I}_{n}-\mathbb{M}\right)$ and $\eta=0 . \mathbb{M} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times n}$ is a binary diagonal matrix with diagonal entries set to 1 or 0 to represent observed and unobserved image pixels respectively. we consider that the unobserved pixels sit in a region in the centre of the image, as illustrated in Fig. 1c. We tackle this problem by using the image-to-image Schrödinger bridge ( $\mathrm{I}^{2} \mathrm{SB}$ ) model of [14], where $p_{T}(\cdot \mid y)=\phi_{n}\left(\cdot ;\left(\mathbb{I}_{n}-\mathbb{M}\right) y, \mathbb{M}\right)$ (see Items 2 and 3 in Section 2.2) and use the sampling scheme (10) with a mapping $s_{\theta}$ defined through a neural network. For the network, we use the implementation ${ }^{9}$ from [14] which was trained for inpainting with a center mask on the ImageNet $256 \times 256$ dataset via (11), with $x_{t}^{(i)}=\mu_{t ; 0, T}\left(x_{0}^{(i)}, y^{(i)}\right)$ defined in (8) deterministically (rather than drawn from $\phi_{n}\left(\cdot ; \mu_{t ; 0, T}, \sigma_{t ; 0, T}^{2} \mathbb{I}_{n}\right)$ ). It is worth noting that, unlike the previous models which rely on stochastic mappings, $\mathrm{I}^{2} \mathrm{SB}$ adopts a deterministic push-forward approach that draws the unknown image pixels from a standard normal distribution that is iteratively pushed forward to the target posterior of interest by using (10) with the noise removed. This corresponds to the mean of the kernel $\mathcal{A}_{t-1 ; 0, t}\left(\cdot \mid x_{0}, x_{t}\right)$ with $x_{0}$ estimated (implicitly) via the function $s_{\theta}$, so the only source of stochasticity comes from the starting $x_{T} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\left(\mathbb{I}_{n}-\mathbb{M}\right) y, \mathbb{M}\right)$. In the continuous limit, $\mathrm{I}^{2} \mathrm{SB}$ corresponds to the solution of an "optimal transport ODE" [14], and hence one still expects the discretisation error to decrease as more steps are added, as is vital for the validity of the MLMC method. Fig. 1c shows an example of an image $x_{0}$ and the corresponding partial observation $y$ that we seek to inpaint, together with a posterior samples as generated by the considered $\mathrm{I}^{2} \mathrm{SB}$ model with $10^{3}$ steps.

For this experiment, we again calculate the marginal second moment of each image pixel, but modify the norm used slightly, taking the Euclidean 2 -norm of only the unobserved pixels in $x_{0}$ (since the other pixels will show no variation, being already determined in the observation $y$ ). Results are shown in Fig. 3c. Again, we observe that MLMC substantially outperforms MC (e.g., to obtain a precision of 0.0012 , it is roughly $9 \times$ more efficient to use MLMC rather than MC). Note that in this case $\beta>1$, so the cost dependence is slightly better than the $\beta=1$ case considered for the other two experiments, as to be expected from (18). The $\alpha, \beta$ for this experiment are also slightly larger than the other two experiments $((0.8,1.4)$ versus $(0.7,1))$. This is due to the fact that the $\mathrm{I}^{2} \mathrm{SB}$ model relies on a deterministic mapping, unlike the models considered previously which used stochastic mappings. Experiments not shown here confirm that switching from stochastic to deterministic sampling leads to increased $\alpha, \beta$. Moreover, the lack of stochasticity, except in the initial condition, leads to small variance for small $\ell$.

# 4 Conclusion 

This paper constitutes a proof of principle of the application of MLMC to Bayesian computation via diffusion models. MLMC could also be applied, for example: to the ensemble averaging performed in [16] for weather prediction models; in combination with different discretisation levels of the images $(16 \times 16,32 \times 32$ etc.) [8]; in combination with the aforementioned strategies for reducing the cost of diffusion models (e.g. pruning, distillation). Typically, the advantages of MLMC will be greater when the underlying variance and uncertainty of the problem is greater - if more NFEs are required, the advantage of MLMC over MC only grows. Therefore, MLMC could be especially beneficial for scientific applications that rely on large-scale foundational diffusion models, such as the new AURORA model of the atmosphere [3]. For future work, having established that MLMC can deliver substantial reductions in computational cost for DMs, it would be natural to explore the combination of MLMC with DM distillation and quantization strategies. Moreover, MLMC could also be used to reduce variance in the training process for DMs, when fine-tuning a foundational DM or training it from scratch, as has been done for other models in, e.g., [26].

# Supplement: Diffusion Models and SDEs 

DMs as SDE samplers One may also formulate DMs as numerical solvers for (reversed) SDEs [24]. We present the following in a more general unconditional context, in which the target distribution is not necessarily a posterior, and is simply denoted $p(\cdot)$. The SDE in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ (where $\left.-A_{t}, B_{t}:[0, T] \mapsto \mathbb{R}_{+}\right)$where $W_{t}$ is a vector in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ of $d$ independent Brownian motions $\left\{W_{t}^{(i)}\right\}_{i=1}^{n}$,

$$
d X_{t}=A_{t} X_{t} d t+B_{t} d W_{t}, \quad X_{0}=x_{0}
$$

has solutions conditioned on $x_{0} X_{t}=\mathrm{e}^{\int_{0}^{t} A_{s} d s}\left(x_{0}+\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{-\int_{0}^{s} A_{u} d u} B_{s} d W_{s}\right)$, which are consequently distributed according to a Gaussian density $K_{t ; 0}\left(\cdot \mid x_{0}\right)=\phi_{n}\left(\cdot ; \mu_{t}\left(x_{0}\right), \Gamma_{t} \mathbb{I}_{n}\right)$. Indeed, in general one has

$$
K_{t ; s}\left(\cdot \mid x_{s}\right)=\phi_{n}\left(\cdot ; \mathrm{e}^{\int_{s}^{t} A_{u} d u} x_{s},\left(\Gamma_{t}-\mathrm{e}^{2 \int_{s}^{t} A_{u} d u} \Gamma_{s}\right) \mathbb{I}_{n}\right)
$$

Denoting the distribution of solutions to the SDE at time $t$ as $p_{t}(\cdot)$, one may choose $A, B$ such that $\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} K_{t ; 0}\left(\cdot \mid x_{0}\right)=\phi_{n}\left(\cdot ; 0, \Gamma_{t} \mathbb{I}_{n}\right)$ [24]. Hence, with $x_{0}$ distributed according to the target $p(\cdot)$,

$$
\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} p_{t}(X) \propto \int_{x_{0}} \lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} \exp \left[-\Gamma_{t}^{-1}\left(X-\mu_{t}\left(x_{0}\right)\right)^{2}\right] p\left(x_{0}\right) d x_{0}=\exp \left[-\Gamma_{t}^{-1} X^{2}\right] \int_{x_{0}} p\left(x_{0}\right) d x_{0}=\phi_{n}\left(X ; 0, \Gamma_{t} \mathbb{I}_{n}\right)
$$

And so by taking $T$ sufficiently large it is possible to reduce the error associated with the approximation $\phi_{n}\left(\cdot ; 0, \Gamma_{t} \mathbb{I}_{n}\right) \approx p_{T}(\cdot)$. The equation (21) has an associated reverse SDE (with $\tau=T-t$ ) [?]

$$
d X_{\tau}^{\tau}=\left[-A_{T-\tau} X_{\tau}^{\tau}+B_{T-\tau}^{2} \nabla \log \left(p_{T-\tau}\left(X_{\tau}^{\tau}\right)\right)\right] d \tau+B_{T-\tau} d W_{\tau}
$$

whose solutions at $\tau=T$, if $X_{0}^{\tau}$ has probability density $p_{T}(\cdot)$, one can show, will give $X_{T}^{\tau}$ distributed according to $p(\cdot)$. Thus, in practice, by taking $A, B$ such that $X_{0}^{\tau}$ is drawn according to the density $\phi_{n}(\cdot) \approx p_{T}(\cdot)$ for fixed $T=1$ (finite time error), training a function $s_{\theta}(x, t) \approx \nabla \log p_{t}(x)$ (model error), discretising (discretisation error) and numerically solving the reverse SDE up to a time $\delta$ close to 0 (truncation error), one may generate approximate samples from the distribution $p\left(x_{0}\right)$ with the same four sources of error, and the same measure of cost (the number of $s_{\theta}$ evaluations) as for the discrete case.

The so-called 'score' $\nabla \log \left(p_{T-\tau}(\cdot)\right)$, which encodes information about $p(\cdot)$, is not analytically available, and so must be approximated (parametrically) by a function $s_{\theta}(x, t)$. Such a function is easily trainable via a dataset of samples $\left\{x_{0}^{(i)}\right\}_{i=1}^{N}$ owing to the law of iterated expectation (with $\left.\mathcal{T}=\left\{t^{(j)}\right\}_{k=1}^{K}\right.$ a random index set of times $\left.t^{(j)} \sim \mathcal{U}_{[0, T]}\right)$

$$
\mathbb{E}_{x, t}\left[\left\|s_{\theta}(x, t)-\nabla \log p_{t}(x)\right\|^{2}\right]=\frac{1}{N|\mathcal{T}|} \approx \sum_{t \in \mathcal{T}} \sum_{i=1}^{N}\left\|s_{\theta}\left(x_{t}^{(i)}, t\right)+\Gamma_{t}^{-1}\left(x_{t}^{(i)}-\mu_{t}\left(x_{0}^{(i)}\right)\right)\right\|^{2}
$$

![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

Figure 4: Above: Conditional denoised samples generated for Experiment 2 [24] using the EM scheme (24) show instability for less than $\approx 2^{5}=32$ steps. Samples generated with fewer steps are unusable for the MLMC technique, since their variance does not fulfill the condition (19). Below: Using the same network $s_{\theta}$ and SDE, but applying the DDIM1 numerical scheme (25) one is able to generate usable samples for MLMC with $2^{2}=4$ steps, which enables one to extract greater benefit from its usage.
since $\nabla \log K_{t ; 0}\left(x \mid x_{0}\right)=-\Gamma_{t}^{-1}\left(x-\mu_{t}\left(x_{0}\right)\right)$ and $x_{t}^{(i)}$ has density $\phi_{n}\left(\cdot ; \mu_{t}\left(x_{0}^{(i)}\right), \Gamma_{t} \xi_{n}\right)$.
The resulting approximate reverse SDE must then be solved numerically, for example via the Euler-Maruyama scheme

$$
X_{\tau_{n+1}}^{r}=X_{\tau_{n}}^{r}+h\left[-A_{T-\tau_{n}} X_{\tau_{n}}^{r}+B_{T-\tau_{n}}^{2} s_{\theta}\left(X_{\tau_{n}}^{r}, T-\tau_{n}\right)\right]+\sqrt{h} B_{T-\tau_{n}} \xi, \quad \xi \sim \mathcal{N}(0,1)
$$

introducing a third source of approximation error (numerical bias) proportional to the timestep discretisation $h=\left|\tau_{n+1}-\tau_{n}\right|$. Note however that one has a great deal of latitude in the choice of the numerical scheme used to solve (23), as discussed below. Typically $p(\cdot)$ will not be sufficiently well-behaved (e.g. it will be supported on a manifold of dimension $<n$ ) and so one solves up to $\tau=T-\delta$ ('truncation') to avoid numerical issues.

Choice of Integrator In the case of DMs explicitly based on SDEs, one has greater latitude in the choice of the update step (10), which may be seen as a step of a numerical integrator [24]. One possibility is the Euler-Maruyama integrator (24) - however this has poor stability properties, which manifest in an inability to generate realistic samples for large step sizes (small number of steps) (see Fig. 4). This is a problem for MLMC since one sees greater benefits from the multilevel nature of the technique, at a wider range of precisions, the more levels one can use.

However, discrete-time DMs of the type in (4) are sometimes able to generate useful samples for $\sim 20$ timesteps, and it has been shown that such models amount to exponential-type integrators combined with a reparametrised expression for the score function $s_{\theta}$ [?]. We summarise the derivation in the succeeding.

In [?], one begins from the expression $\nabla \log K_{s ; 0}\left(x_{s} \mid x_{0}\right)$ (since $\mu_{s}\left(x_{0}\right)=\mathrm{e}^{\int_{0}^{s} A_{u} d u} x_{0}$ is linear)

$$
\nabla \log K_{s ; 0}\left(x_{s} \mid x_{0}\right)=-\Gamma_{s}^{-1}\left(x_{s}-\mu_{s} x_{0}\right)
$$

which may be rearranged to give $x_{0}=\mu_{s}^{-1}\left(x_{s}+\Gamma_{s} \nabla \log K_{s ; 0}\left(x_{s} \mid x_{0}\right)\right)$ and thus it holds for any two times $t, s$ that

$$
\nabla \log K_{t ; 0}\left(x_{t} \mid x_{0}\right)=-\Gamma_{t}^{-1}\left[x_{t}-\mathrm{e}^{\int_{\tau}^{t} A_{u} d u}\left(x_{s}+\Gamma_{s} \nabla \log K_{s ; 0}\left(x_{s} \mid x_{0}\right)\right)\right]
$$

Then one may modify the RSDE (23) by replacing $\nabla \log p_{t}(x) \approx \nabla \log K_{t ; 0}\left(x \mid x_{0}\right)$ and using the expression above. Denoting $A(T-\tau)=A_{\tau}^{r}$ etc. one has

$$
\begin{aligned}
d X_{\tau}^{r} & =\left[-A_{\tau}^{r} X_{\tau}^{r}-\frac{\left(B_{\tau}^{r}\right)^{2}}{\Gamma_{\tau}^{r}}\left[X_{\tau}^{r}-\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{\tau_{s}}^{r} A_{u}^{r} d u}\left(X_{\tau_{s}}^{r}+\Gamma_{\tau_{s}}^{r} \nabla \log p_{\tau_{s}}^{r}\left(X_{\tau_{s}}^{r}\right)\right)\right]\right] d \tau+B_{\tau}^{r} d W_{\tau} \\
& =\left[-\left(A_{\tau}^{r}+\frac{\left(B_{\tau}^{r}\right)^{2}}{\Gamma_{\tau}^{r}}\right) X_{\tau}^{r}+\frac{\left(B_{\tau}^{r}\right)^{2}}{\Gamma_{\tau}^{r}} \mathrm{e}^{-\int_{\tau_{s}}^{r} A_{u}^{r} d u}\left(X_{\tau_{s}}^{r}+\Gamma_{\tau_{s}}^{r} \nabla \log p_{\tau_{s}}^{r}\left(X_{\tau_{s}}^{r}\right)\right)\right] d \tau+B_{\tau}^{r} d W_{\tau}
\end{aligned}
$$

where we must change the direction of integration ${ }^{10}$. This has exact solution between $\left[\tau_{s}=T-\right.$ $\left.s, \tau_{t}=T-t\right]$ (replacing ${ }^{11} \nabla \log p_{\tau_{s}}^{r}\left(X_{\tau_{s}}^{r}\right) \equiv f_{\tau_{s}}\left(X_{\tau_{s}}^{r}\right)$ )

$$
\begin{aligned}
X_{\tau_{t}}^{r} & =\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{\tau_{s}}^{\tau_{t}} A_{\tau}^{r}+\frac{\left(B_{\tau}^{r}\right)^{2}}{\Gamma_{\tau}^{r}} d \tau}\left[X_{\tau_{s}}^{r}+\int_{\tau_{s}}^{\tau_{t}} \frac{\left(B_{\tau}^{r}\right)^{2}}{\Gamma_{\tau}^{r}} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{\tau_{s}}^{\tau} \frac{\left(B_{\tau}^{r}\right)^{2}}{\Gamma_{u}^{r}} d u} d \tau\left(X_{\tau_{s}}^{r}+\Gamma_{\tau_{s}}^{r} f_{\tau_{s}}\left(X_{\tau_{s}}^{r}\right)\right)+\int_{\tau_{s}}^{\tau_{t}} B_{\tau}^{r} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{\tau_{s}}^{\tau} A_{u}^{r}+\frac{\left(B_{\tau}^{r}\right)^{2}}{\Gamma_{u}^{r}} d u} d W_{\tau}\right] \\
& =\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{\tau_{s}}^{\tau_{t}} A_{\tau}^{r} d \tau}\left[X_{\tau_{s}}^{r}+\left(1-\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{\tau_{s}}^{\tau_{t}} \frac{\left(B_{\tau}^{r}\right)^{2}}{\Gamma_{\tau}^{r}} d \tau}\right) \Gamma_{\tau_{s}}^{r} f_{\tau_{s}}\left(X_{\tau_{s}}^{r}\right)\right]+\int_{\tau_{s}}^{\tau_{t}} B_{\tau}^{r} \mathrm{e}^{-\int_{\tau_{s}}^{\tau_{t}} A_{u}^{r}+\frac{\left(B_{\tau}^{r}\right)^{2}}{\Gamma_{u}^{r}} d u} d W_{\tau} \\
& =\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{\tau_{s}}^{\tau_{t}} A_{\tau}^{r} d \tau} X_{\tau_{s}}^{r}+\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{\tau_{s}}^{\tau_{t}} A_{\tau}^{r} d \tau} \Gamma_{\tau_{s}}^{r}-\Gamma_{\tau_{t}}^{r} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{\tau_{s}}^{\tau_{t}} A_{\tau}^{r} d \tau}\right) f_{\tau_{s}}\left(X_{\tau_{s}}^{r}\right)+\sqrt{\Gamma_{\tau_{t}}^{r}} \int_{\tau_{s}}^{\tau_{t}} \frac{B_{\tau}^{r}}{\sqrt{\Gamma_{\tau}^{r}}} \mathrm{e}^{-\int_{\tau}^{\tau_{t}} \frac{\left(B_{\tau}^{r}\right)^{2}}{2 \Gamma_{u}^{r}} d u} d W_{\tau}
\end{aligned}
$$

This is then simulated numerically via the following scheme, called DDIM1 (with $s>t$ )

$$
X_{\tau_{t}}^{r}=\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{\tau} A_{u} d u} X_{\tau_{s}}^{r}+\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{t}^{\tau} A_{u} d u} \Gamma_{s}-\Gamma_{t} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{t}^{\tau} A_{u} d u}\right) s_{\theta}\left(X_{\tau_{s}}^{r}, s\right)+\sqrt{\Gamma_{t}\left(1-\Gamma_{t} \Gamma_{s}^{-1} \mathrm{e}^{2 \int_{t}^{\tau} A_{u} d u}\right)} \xi, \quad \xi \sim \mathcal{N}(0,1)
$$

which is clearly equivalent to the discrete process (10). To adapt the sampling to Algorithm 2, one needs to find the analogue of (12). One notes that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sqrt{\Gamma_{\tau_{t}}^{r}} \int_{\tau_{s}}^{\tau_{t}} & \frac{B_{\tau}^{r}}{\sqrt{\Gamma_{\tau}^{r}}} \mathrm{e}^{-\int_{\tau}^{\tau_{t}} \frac{\left(B_{\tau}^{r}\right)^{2}}{2 \Gamma_{u}^{r}} d u} d W_{\tau}=\sqrt{\Gamma_{\tau_{t}}^{r}}\left[\int_{\tau_{s}}^{\tau_{t^{\prime}}} \frac{B_{\tau}^{r}}{\sqrt{\Gamma_{\tau}^{r}}} \mathrm{e}^{-\int_{\tau}^{\tau_{t}} \frac{\left(B_{\tau}^{r}\right)^{2}}{2 \Gamma_{u}^{r}} d u} d W_{\tau}+\int_{\tau_{t^{\prime}}}^{\tau_{t}} \frac{B_{\tau}^{r}}{\sqrt{\Gamma_{\tau}^{r}}} \mathrm{e}^{-\int_{\tau}^{\tau_{t}} \frac{\left(B_{\tau}^{r}\right)^{2}}{2 \Gamma_{u}^{r}} d u} d W_{\tau}\right] \\
& =\sqrt{\Gamma_{\tau_{t}}^{r}}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{\tau_{t^{\prime}}}^{\tau_{t}} \frac{\left(B_{\tau}^{r}\right)^{2}}{2 \Gamma_{u}^{r}} d u} \int_{\tau_{s}}^{\tau_{t^{\prime}}} \frac{B_{\tau}^{r}}{\sqrt{\Gamma_{\tau}^{r}}} \mathrm{e}^{-\int_{\tau}^{\tau_{t^{\prime}}} \frac{\left(B_{\tau}^{r}\right)^{2}}{2 \Gamma_{u}^{r}} d u} d W_{\tau}+\int_{\tau_{t^{\prime}}}^{\tau_{t}} \frac{B_{\tau}^{r}}{\sqrt{\Gamma_{\tau}^{r}}} \mathrm{e}^{-\int_{\tau}^{\tau_{t}} \frac{\left(B_{\tau}^{r}\right)^{2}}{2 \Gamma_{u}^{r}} d u} d W_{\tau}\right] \\
& =\sqrt{\Gamma_{\tau_{t}}^{r}}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{\tau_{t^{\prime}}}^{\tau_{t}} \frac{\left(B_{\tau}^{r}\right)^{2}}{2 \Gamma_{u}^{r}} d u} \frac{\eta_{\tau_{s}, \tau_{t^{\prime}}}}{\sqrt{\Gamma_{\tau_{t^{\prime}}}^{r}}}+\frac{\eta_{\tau_{t^{\prime}}, \tau_{t}}}{\sqrt{\Gamma_{\tau_{t}}^{r}}}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\eta_{\tau_{s}, \tau_{t}}=\sqrt{\Gamma_{\tau_{t}}^{r}} \int_{\tau_{s}}^{\tau_{t}} \frac{B_{\tau}^{r}}{\sqrt{\Gamma_{\tau}^{r}}} \mathrm{e}^{-\int_{\tau}^{\tau_{t}} \frac{\left(B_{\tau}^{r}\right)^{2}}{2 \Gamma_{u}^{r}} d u} d W_{\tau}
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{10}$ Since $\int_{\mathcal{T}-\tau_{s}}^{T-\tau} A_{u} d u=-\int_{\tau_{s}}^{\tau} A_{T-v} d v=-\int_{\tau_{s}}^{\tau} A_{v}^{r} d v$.
    ${ }^{11}$ And using that $d / d t \Gamma_{t}=B_{t}^{2}+2 A_{t} \Gamma_{t}$ so that $d / d \tau \Gamma_{\tau}^{r}=-\left(B_{\tau}^{r}\right)^{2}-2 A_{\tau}^{r} \Gamma_{\tau}^{r}$.

is the noise added in a step from $\tau_{s} \rightarrow \tau_{t}$. Thus given two fine increments $\eta_{\tau_{s}, \tau_{s-1}}, \eta_{\tau_{s-1}, \tau_{s-2}}$, one may generate the coarse increment $\eta_{\tau_{s}, \tau_{s-2}}$ via

$$
\eta_{\tau_{s}, \tau_{s-2}}=\sqrt{\Gamma_{\tau_{s-2}}^{r}}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\int_{\tau_{s-1}}^{\tau_{s-2}} \frac{\left(B_{t}^{r}\right)^{2}}{2 \Gamma_{0}} d u} \frac{\eta_{\tau_{s}, \tau_{s-1}}}{\sqrt{\Gamma_{\tau_{s-1}}^{r}}}+\frac{\eta_{\tau_{s-1}, \tau_{s-2}}}{\sqrt{\Gamma_{\tau_{s-2}}^{r}}}\right]=\operatorname{scaler}(s) \eta_{\tau_{s}, \tau_{s-1}}+\eta_{\tau_{s-1}, \tau_{s-2}}
$$

It can be seen that an iterative update of the form (12) is also suitable to sum the fine increments for general $M$.

abstract:
Generative diffusion models have recently emerged as a powerful strategy to
perform stochastic sampling in Bayesian inverse problems, delivering remarkably
accurate solutions for a wide range of challenging applications. However,
diffusion models often require a large number of neural function evaluations
per sample in order to deliver accurate posterior samples. As a result, using
diffusion models as stochastic samplers for Monte Carlo integration in Bayesian
computation can be highly computationally expensive, particularly in
applications that require a substantial number of Monte Carlo samples for
conducting uncertainty quantification analyses. This cost is especially high in
large-scale inverse problems such as computational imaging, which rely on large
neural networks that are expensive to evaluate. With quantitative imaging
applications in mind, this paper presents a Multilevel Monte Carlo strategy
that significantly reduces the cost of Bayesian computation with diffusion
models. This is achieved by exploiting cost-accuracy trade-offs inherent to
diffusion models to carefully couple models of different levels of accuracy in
a manner that significantly reduces the overall cost of the calculation,
without reducing the final accuracy. The proposed approach achieves a
$4\times$-to-$8\times$ reduction in computational cost w.r.t. standard
techniques across three benchmark imaging problems.
